private_information: Can only interact with vowel blocks: A, E, I
Can hold at most one block at a time
If AgentV is holding a block, AgentC may not place a block onto that held block
AgentV.goal: Help reconfigure the blocks to reach the target two-stack configuration while only manipulating vowels and respecting holding and stack-count constraints.

private_information: Can only interact with consonant blocks: B, C, D, F, G
Can hold at most one block at a time
If AgentC is holding a block, AgentV may not place a block onto that held block
AgentC.goal: Help reconfigure the blocks to reach the target two-stack configuration while only manipulating consonants and respecting holding and stack-count constraints.

private_information: There are two operational agents with complementary block interaction constraints.
At most 3 stacks may exist on the table at any time.
Agents alternate or interleave moves but must obey mutual holding/placement constraints.
orchestrator.goal: Generate a PDDL domain and problem that models the two-agent block-rearrangement task, encoding agent-specific action capabilities, holding constraints, stack-count limit (<=3), and the initial and goal stack configurations.

goal.description: Two stacks on the table: (bottom->top) Stack1: F,C,I,G and Stack2: A,B,D,E. F and A are directly on the table.

public_information: Blocks: A, B, C, D, E, F, G, I
At most 3 stacks may exist on the table at any time
A move consists of lifting the top block of a stack (if allowed for the agent) and placing it onto another stack or onto the table to form a new stack
An empty stack ceases to exist
Consonant blocks: B, C, D, F, G

orchestrator.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL problems. You will be provided information about the environment and the capabilities and knowledge of the agents which interact in the environment. You always provide a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that describes the planning problem. Enclose the pddl domain between <domain></domain> tags, and the pddl problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep the actions for different agents distinct, so that there is no confusion as to which agent performs which action. Encode holding constraints, stack-count limit (<=3), and agent-specific allowed blocks explicitly.
orchestrator.prompt:
Your name is orchestrator.
Initial information about the environment: {environment->init}.
Goal for the environment: {environment->goal}.
The public information is: {environment->public_information}.
AgentV's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->AgentV->private_information}.
AgentC's constraints are: {agents->agent_details->AgentC->private_information}.
Think step by step and provide a PDDL domain and problem that encapsulate the integrated model, respecting the constraints of each agent. Model agents AgentV and AgentC as separate actors with actions to pick and place only their permitted blocks, enforce single-held-block per agent, mutual constraint preventing placing on a held block, and ensure the number of stacks never exceeds 3. Do not make assumptions beyond the given information. There is no need for anything else beyond producing the pddl files.
